all_questions.question: What is the estimated maximum number of elements in a one-hot representation vector before it becomes too large to be practically manageable?
all_questions.context: We need to somehow reduce that because practically we can fit vectors or the rest of the computation and so on can reasonably work if we have 30 to 80 thousand elements in this one-hot representation vectors.

all_questions.question: What is an alternative approach to reducing the size of a vocabulary, besides using subword units?
all_questions.context: So the very simple idea is to use subord units. So instead of the original words and there would be all those two million Czech words, word forms.

all_questions.question: What type of linguistic units are suggested as a good size for reducing vocabulary in languages with productive morphology?
all_questions.context: You can go to smaller units linguistically motivated such as syllables or morphemes that would reduce that the size of the vocabulary but with productive morphology that we know from Czech or compounding languages such as German

all_questions.question: What is the general idea behind the approach of combining frequent pairs of characters to produce large units?
all_questions.context: The general idea is that you you will start with the alphabet as the set of allowed units and your vocabulary size is still pretty much like unused and you will combine the most frequent pairs of characters to produce large units.

all_questions.question: What happens to words that are very frequent in the resulting vocabulary created by this approach?
all_questions.context: And then in the next step you will again combine some two units in your current vocabulary to produce yet a large unit. And you do this until the vocabulary size is is fully occupied.
